questions.question_text:
You have 1,000 on-premises Windows 11 Pro devices that are onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender XDR.

You identify that an attacker performed the following actions on a device:

â€¢ Modified the filesystem path of a registry-based antivirus exclusion
â€¢ Downloaded a malicious file to the file system path

You initiate a live response session on the device.

You need to undo the registry change.

Which command should you run?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - remediate - is the correct answer to remediate the registry 
B - registry - this just shows the registries, you cannot do anything else 
C - scan - this will scan and remediate malware, not modified registries
D - analyze - same as scan, it does not provide any form of restoration 

Ref- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/live-response

questions.question_text:
Your on-premises network contains two Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) domains named contoso.com and fabrikam.com. Contoso.com contains a group named Group1. Fabrikam.com contains a group named Group2.

You have a Microsoft Sentinel workspace named WS1 that contains a scheduled query rule named Rule1. Rule1 generates alerts in response to anomalous AD DS security events. Each alert creates an incident.

You need to implement an incident triage solution that meets the following requirements:

â€¢ Security incidents from contoso.com must be assigned to Group1.
â€¢ Security incidents from fabrikam.com must be assigned to Group2.
â€¢ Administrative effort must be minimized.

What should you include in the solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
ChatGTP: 
âœ… Correct answer: D. Two automation rules assigned to Rule1
ðŸ’¡ Explanation:

To assign incidents to different groups based on the originating domain (contoso.com or fabrikam.com) with minimal administrative effort, the best approach is to:

 Create two automation rules, each with a condition to check for indicators (like hostname, domain, or event source).

 Use the rules to automatically assign incidents to Group1 or Group2.

âœ… Why two automation rules (Option D) is correct:

 Automation rules in Microsoft Sentinel can act on incident properties such as title, custom details, or mapped entities.

 Each domain (contoso.com / fabrikam.com) would likely be identifiable via a field in the alert/incident (e.g., domain name, hostname suffix).

 Creating one rule per domain ensures precise and maintainable logic, with clear ownership per domain.

 Requires less overhead than scripting or maintaining complex playbooks.

choices.C: one automation rule assigned to Rule1
choices.A: a playbook that is triggered by the creation of an incident
choices.B: a playbook that is triggered by the creation of an alert
choices.D: two automation rules assigned to Rule1

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.

You have the following KQL query.

//IMG//


You need to ensure that you can create a Microsoft Defender XDR custom detection rule by using the query.

What should you add to the query?

choices.A: | summarize (Timestamp, ReportId)=arg_max(Timestamp, ReportId), count() by DeviceId
choices.C: | summarize (Timestamp, DeviceName)=arg_min(Timestamp, DeviceName), count() by DeviceId

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It was om the test.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Office 365.

You need to build a hunting query that will list events involving potentially malicious emails that were detected but NOT removed successfully from mailboxes after delivery. The solution must ensure that the events are correlated with the sign-in events of the email recipients.

How should you complete the query? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
ZAP - if ZAP fails (ActionResult == "Error"), the email is detected, but not removed. 
AccountUpn - this correlates with the user email

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a Microsoft Sentinel workspace named SW1.

In SW1, you enable User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA).

You need to use KQL to perform the following tasks:

â€¢ View the entity data that has fields for each type of entity.
â€¢ Assess the quality of rules by analyzing how well a rule performs.

Which table should you use in KQL for each task? To answer, drag the appropriate tables to the correct tasks. Each table may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
This question was in the exam 27/04/2024.

BehaviorAnalytics and Anomalies.

comments.content: Another perla. The CORRECT table for assessing rule quality is BehaviorAnalyticsRuleStats. But of course, that isn't even an option. So we go with Anomalies.

discussion.content:
Correct Answers:
View entity data: BehaviorAnalytics
Assess rule quality: Anomalies
